div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: BOVRIL
div.p: Qu'est ce que c'est BOVRIL?
BOVRIL est le produit garanti du meilleur bétail qui existe.
C'est un repas à la minute qui protège contre les intempéries.
"BOVRIL" et "Bonne Cuisine" sont deux mots qui disent la même chose.

BOVRIL répond a une nécessité; il est non seulement une boisson delicieuse et saine, mais il est encore indispensable pour préparer instantanement des soupes et sauces appétisantes. Bovril n'a pas de rival pour corser les plats les plus récherches.
BOVRIL répare l'organisme fatigué.

Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
FRIDAY, DECEMBER 21 1906.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: H.M.S. Carnarvon.
H.M.S. Carnarvon is expected to arrive at Alexandria from Malta in a few days.
A Fatal Fall.
A native girl, aged 7, fell from the third storey of a house at Sohag, and was killed on the spot. The Brindley Mall.
The mail for Europe, viâ Port Said and Brindisi, will close at the G. P. O., Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Sunday. Dervish Prisoners.
It is rumoured that the Ministry of War will shortly release some of the Dervish captives imprisoned at Damietta.
Egyptian State Railways.
The contract for the supply of baskets to this administration has been given to Tolba Mohamed, of Cairo, at 16 } milk for small and $1 mill. for large baskets.
Bohera Kuttabs.
The distribution of grants-in-aid to the fikis of the kattabs in Behera Mondirieb 'took place yesterday, under the presidency of the Mondir, at Damanhur Moudirieh. Nellenlo Assizes.

Yesterday afternoon the Hellenic A88z9 Coert at Alexandria sentepood V. Anastassiou to two and a half years' imprisonment for & burglary committed at a shop in a village in the interior last April. He was sentenced on the evidence of two natives, who were hostile witnesses.
Egyptian Institute.

A meeting of the Institute will be held at Cairo on Monday, 24th inst., at 5 p.m., when Yacoub Pasba Artin will read a paper entitled "Lczange, dé ou cachet," M. Barois will present the financial report for 1906, and there will be an election of office bearers and of the publications committee.
Local Commissions

New local commissions have been created at Sennoures and Simbellawein. The credits for the local commissions have been impressed in the following on.ses and in the following amounts: Tantah, Massourab, and Damabhoor, L.B. 5,000; Beni Sons, L.B. 70;8pes and Assouan, LE. 500; Bengha and Girgeh, LE-450 ; Damietta and Minieh, LE. 400; Bohag, L.E. 300; Fayoum, LE. 250.
Terrible Accident

A fearful accident took place in Old Cairo on Tuesday evening. A tram inspector, Nicolas Thoomaides by name, was on the tail board of a tram, when he was strack on the back by a dart laden with wood. He lost his footbold, and falling under the wheels of the tram, was mangled to death. The body lay for one hour and a half on the ground before the arrival of the amour and the moswin of police.
WIDENING BOULAC ROAD.

The scheme of widening this important artery of Cairo is now being put into execution by a large number of workmen under the superintendence of an architect of the Tarzim, starting from Aboul Bla mesque. The road is to be widened from 12 to 25 metres, and & junction affected in it between the Ain Beba and Ataba el Khadra tramways.
CAPE TO CAIRO RAILWAY.

The "Metropole" of Antwerp announces that negotiations are now in progress between the British Government and the Congo State, in view of the cession to England of a strip of land over which the Cape to Cairo Railway should run. It is further stated that it was in order to settle the conditions of this conscious that Major Cabra bas lately been ordered to leave Bombs for the eastern frontier of the State.
EGYPTIAN MINES EXPLORATION.
Mr. C. J. A ford has furnished the following Bomisary of the month's operations: --

SEMNA MINB. December 1st. Main Shaft First Lovell East India 72 teeth, last nine feet of vein averages 66 inches wide with 18 dwts gold per ton. First Leve! West 95 feet, last 18 feet vein averages 26 inches wide with 11 dwts gold per ton. Main Widze down 23 feet, vein wider than 6 tt. side of winze carries 23.5 dwts gold per top. N° 1 shaft First Level West 209 feet, last 94 feet of vein averages 21 inches wide with 13 dute gold per ton. A widze has been commenced in the vein 30 feet Eset of N° 1 Shaft. N 8 Shaft First Level B18t 169 feet, last 98 feet of vein averages 50 inches wide with 10 dwts gold per ton. This drive will shortly connect with Main Shaft First Level West when the working conditions will be much improved.
NOTICE.

The Shareholders of WALKER & MEIMA RACHI LIMITED are invited to set on Saturday text, the 92nd-inst, st 4.30 p.m. at the Continental Hotel, Cairc, to ascertain the Company's present position, and consult as to the measures to be taken to ensure unity in the administration of the Company's affairs.

Cairo, 18th December 1906.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN NATIONALISTS.
div.p: MR. ROBERTSON REFUTES DR. NIMR.

Mr. J. M. Robertson, M.P., replies in the "Times" to the statements made by Dr. Paris Nimr in "Al Mokattam" concerning his attitude towards the Egyptian Nationalist movement. In the course of his letter be says: I think it Necessary to state that, while Dr. Nimr bas' cited with general accuracy what I said to him as to the attitude of Radicals towards the administration of Egypt, he has at two points ascribed to me bis own views. He took no photos during his conversation with me, and has thus illustrated the usual fatality of the interview. The phrase They would never abandon Egypt to the Tarks or to itself." 88 regards the words italicized, conveys the exact opposite of my long avowed view of our duties in Egypt. Dr. Nimr farther represents me al contouring with him in that policy of mutual separation among the sections of the Egyptian Press in which he plays his unfortunate part, but with which I have no sympathy whatever. Until the other day the pro-official journals at Cairo sedo lovely called me (as they did every other member who discussed the Dennis Wai trials) the mouthpiece of Mastapha Kamel Pasha. Now they describe me as aspersing him. The two statements are alike false.
Naturally Dr. Nimr says nothing of my criticism of his own policy, which I pressed somewhat perilously on his attention. -
MUSTAPHA KAMEL INTERVIEWED.
The following telegram from Paris is publieh. ed in yesterday's issue of "Al Lewa" :
An important interview with Maetapba Pachs Kamel has been published in the

Pall Mall Gazette." In the course of the interview the Pasha made a declaration on the subject of his absolute independence, and he deduced the strongest roots to show that wbat bad recently been published as to the Khedive's relations with the Nationalist movement was entirely groundless. He also contradicted the statements made in the Times" and declared that the aim and object of the "Beyptian Standard” were founded on an honourable and a practical basis..

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive, who attended midday prayers at Montozsh Mosque to-day, is leaving for Cairo this evening.
His Highness will go to Abdeen on Monday morning, when be will grant private audiences to some notables and officials, and in the afternoon bis Highness will preside over the Council of Ministers.
Shortly after his return to Cairo the Khedive will visit the new hospital of the Egyptian Army at Abbassieh, where prepara. tions are being made for his Highness' reception.
The Khedive bas ordered five locomotive, for the Maripat Railway.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: The business before the Council of Ministers, which will meet at 3 p.m. on Monday at Abdeen Palace, under the presidency of the Khedive, will be to approve the list of grades and decorations to be conferred on Accession Day; as well as the grant of a gratification equal to a month's salary to Government officials who have been in service since 1904.

div.head: THE MAHROUSSA.
div.p: It is stated that Messrs. A. and J. Inglis & Co., of Glasgow, intend meaning the Egyptian Government for the sum of LE, 110,000, being their bill for the renovation of the Khedivial yacht Mabron888. The price put forward by the Government is L.E. 90,000. On the other hand, it is said that the budgetary estimates for 1907 allow for the firm's claim.

div.head: NEW PENSION LAW.
div.p: The new Pension Law is to be published shortly. Expert advice on the subject is of the opinion that three and not five per cent. Bhuld be deducted from the salaries of officiale, and the som 80 deducted placed to interest. To compensate for this deduction, one-sixth of the period of service will be deducted from the toll time. A fall pension will be granted after forty-five years' service; two-thirds after 35 years; balf after 25, and One-fourth after 15 years.

div.head: FINANCE MINISTRY.
div.p: The inspectorates of the Ministry of Finance have been divided as follows:
Galion bieh and Sbarkieh.-Mr. Paterson, Salep Effendi Mokhter, and Mr. Hillas.
Dakbalieh and Gharbieh-Mr. Dallin, Ab med Effendi Sadik, and Mr. Hogg.
Menoufia and Bebera.--Mr. Burnett Stewart and Abd el Aziz Effendi Abeza.
Ghizeh, Beni Sosef, and Payout.-Mohamed Effendi Mouses and Mohamed Effendi Fuad. | Minieb and Assiont.--Mr. McKillop and Mohamed Effendi Ran zi.
Girgeh, Kepeh and Assouan-Mr. Wild and Mehamed Effendi Fabmi.
The Ministry of Finance has appointed Gasfer Effendi inspector with a monthly Salary of L.B. 22 and confirmed the appointment of Mr. Johnson and Mt. Arthar Thomas assistant inspectors.

div.head: THE POSTAL BUDGET.
div.p: FORTHCOMING REFORMS.
We understand that the Postal Budget for 1907 has been approved by the Ministry of Finance.

It provides for strengthening the existing staff and services to cope with the extraordi. nary increase of traffic, an excess of about 8,000,000 letters and parcels over last year having already been dealt with.
Inland postcards are reduced from 3 to 2 milliemes in price, and insurance fees on inland insured parcels are reduced from 10 to 5 milliemes per unit of L.E. 12.
Proposals put forward by the Postmaster. General for new offices, rural lines, and house delivery of parcels have been postponed to another year.

div.head: ITALIAN SAILORS' STRIKE.
div.p: As the strike of sailors in Italian porte bas extended to postal steamers the Florio RabattiDO 8.8. Singapore, wbieb was due at Alexandria on Sunday Dext, is detained at Legboin, and the same company's S.B. Bosforo at Brindisi. It is at present impossible to say when these steamers can take to ses again.
The sailing for Italy of Thursday, 27th inst., will be carried out by the 8.8. Perseo, at present in Syria.
The 8.8. Orione, which is due tomorrow will leave for Italy on Sunday at 8 p.m.

div.head: CONFERENCE SPELTERINI
div.p: Eduard Spelterini, le célèbre aéro dante, & dopé bier soir, au New Khedivial Hotel, une séance de projection de photographies en ballon qui ont excité le plus vit intérêt et accompagnées d'explications données par le Prof. Blandevier, qui a exposé les travaux de Spelterini, 868 expéditions, ainsi que ce qu'on peut en attendre encore. Des cartes, des dessins et des diagrammes orientaient les auditeurs sur ses voyages dans les Alpes et retraçait les zones les plus sensationnelles de ses expéditions. C'était une suite ininterrompue d'ima. ges lumineuses projetées sur l'écran de la vaste salle dont le tond représentait l'atmosphère au milieu duquel on admirait les sommets neigeux des Alpes dans toute leur majestueuse splen. deur.

Le capitaine Spelterini est un homme cintré. pide, qui a effectué jusqu'à ce jour 589 ascensions. Il possède 2 orissettes de voies qui, projetées sur la toile, enivrent les regards et réservent aux spectateurs les jouissances les plus élevées qu'il soit possible d'imaginer, comme Aladin et es lampe miraculeuse. Si la photographie a atteint aujourd'hui on si haut degré de perfection, si le cinématographe et la photo one leurs nous montrent des images parfaites, elles ne sont que la reproduction exacte de ce que nos yeux peuvent voir sur la terre. Mais les paysages vus de haut en bas, dans toutes leurs faces à la fois, donnent aux yeux âne im. pression toute nouvelle qui excite an plas bant point la surprise et l'étonnement. C'est ce que l'on trouve dans les épreuves uniques et inédites da capitaine Spelterini.

Dans los rues de Zurich à 1,000 mètres de hauteur les gros édifices sont encore clairement reconnaissables et les rues ressemblent à des rubans d'argent. Les différences d'architecture entre la vieille et la nouvelle ville apparaissent Dettement quoiqu'en perspective raccourcie.

Les photographies des Alpes sont tout 06 que l'on peut voir de plus incomparable. Le Mönch, Biger, la Jungfrau, les Mischabel, le Dome, le Mont Robe, le Cervin, l'Aletaobhorn, eto. défilent sur l'écran dans toute leur majesté. Leurs massee noires, coupées par l'éblouissante nappe des glaciers avec une netteté et une clarté extraordinaires sont un enfantement pont les yeux. L'aéronaute présente dans ce groupe d'images 84 diapositives, tons plus beaux les Uns que les autres. Non moins intéressants sont les 21 diapositives se rapportant à l'Egypte où Spelterini a fait 8 Ascensions à quelques années d'intervalle; mais oe n'est qu'à son second voyage qu'il & commandé à s'opposer de photographie. Les diapositives qu'il en a rapporté forment un grand contraste avec ses vues des Alpes. Ses expéditions comprennent le Caire, le Nil, la ville des Morts, les tom. beaux des Élites, les merveilleu 308 pyramides de Khéops, Khephren et-Menkara, de jolies vues du désert. Toutes ont été très bien ex. pliquées.

Un aéronaute seul peut se faire un idée exacte et dire la peine et la patience qu'il faut pour composer une pareille collection. Quelles difficultés énormes de faut il pas vaincre pour conduire un ballon dans le voisinage dangereux des glaciers de l'Eiger, de la Yang Frs et en tirer des épreuves photographiques 1 Chaque aéronaute sait parfaitement quels ennais cause déjà la traversée de simples obstacle comme une forêt de moyenne étendue on la gorge d'un cours d'eau ; à plus forte raison est-il anxieux et perplexe lorsqu'il s'agit de s'élever plus haut, et le photographe Spelterioi doit oompter sveo l'aréonadto da même nom en présence des dangers naturels qui se présentent. On sait que les grandes chaînes de montagnes causent des irrégularités dans le régime des vents ; on peut donc s'imaginer quelles difficult cultés rencontre celui qui veut passer au-dessus des plus hauts sommets à 4.000 m. et s'orienter dans les nuages et le dédale des montagn98 qu'il traverse
Cette conférence & ea, à Alexandrie, comme partout, le plus grand Bucoes.
Ajoutons que l'amabilité que Monsieur Reinsperger, directeur da New Khedivial Hotel a témoigné à Spelterini loi fait le plus grand honneur.

div.head: FAYOUM NOTES.
div.p: INCREASE OF CRIME.
( FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT. )

Medinet el Payoom, Thursday. The bomber of crimes committed in the Fayoum from January 1 up to the end of November of this year is 252, which shows an increase on the figures of last year of 70, the total daring that period being 182. 'I bese figures afford food for reflection. It is difficult to assign & Cause for this great increase of crime. Some people bere think that the new arrangement as regards ghaffari malabiz is unsatisfactory and odworkable, while others lean to the opinion that criminals have no longer any dread of imprisonment, so long as their place of tem. porary confinement is more comfortable than their own homes. The outstanding fact remains, however, that public security in this province is not what it ought to be, and the remedy must be sought by the authorities. Big Sale of Land.

M. Hilla, of Cairo, has disposed of his Fayoum estater, covering an area of about 2,100 led dang, Bassel Bey, the Bedouin, for L.B. 195,000. This price includes all the esbebs, live stook, and agricultural implements. Increase in Kuttabs.

A meeting was held at the Mondirieh yesterday for the purpose of distributing to the fikis the grants-in-aid of the kuttabs in the district. It appears there has been a large iporoase in the number of these schools during the last two years. Irrigation.

Mr. Job Langley, Inspector General of Irrigation in Upper Egypt, paid a visit to the Fayoum yesterday, in the company of the inspector of Fayoum and the chief engineers of Beni Souef and Payout. They bad under consideration the question as to what damage might accrue to the banks of the upper canals if the Lagoon Bridge were closed. It was finally decided to close the bridge this morning, and the Babr Youssef Canal will consequently be dry for 20 days. Daring that period the Fayoom will be deprived of drinking water. I don't know what steps the Public Health Department have taken to cope with this lack of drinking water, but it is to be hoped the consequences will not be so serious as one is inclined to believe.

div.head: LES INCIDENTS DE LA BOURSE
div.p: DU CAIRE.
UNE SOLUTION.
Nous lisons dans la “Bourse Égyptienne" :

Les récents incidents ont clairement démontré que le Comité de la Corporation des Agents de Change du Caire n'est nullement à la hauteur de sa táshe et qu'il ne jouit de la 000fianoe de personne ; on raconte même, et nous le croyons sans peine, qu'aucun de ces messieurs n'a la moindre confiance en ses collè. gaes.
Malgré cela, et bien qu'ils se sachent l'objet de la risée publique, ils se cramponnent indécemment à un poste dont ils sont manifestement indignes..

Il est donc temps que ces Messieurs donnent leur démission en bloc, pour être remplacés par un Comité sérieux, honnête, et se rendant compte de la ligne de conduite à suivre, pour tirer la Corporation des Agents de Change de l'impasse dans laquelle elle se trouve saoulée.

Si is retraite da Comité actuel ne s'effectue pas dans le plus bref délai possible, il en résulte une grave responsabilité pour tous les membres de la Corporation. Il deviendrait, en effet, impossible à quiconque, fait-il muni des meilleures intentions du monde, de dégager la Corporation des Agents de Change da Cairo de la situation à la fois grote:que et intenable dans laquelle Bon Comité l'a bénévolement fourvoyée.

p.hi: Il n'y a donc, répétons-le, qu'un moyen de solution pratique: démission du Comité en entier et démission immédiate.

div.p: Ce pas fait, il deviendrait possible, sinon de réparer toutes les fautes commises, da moins de prévenir de nouvelles irrégularités dont les conséquences pourraient désormais être incollables.
On avisera ensuite avec beaucoup de sang froid et de tarot à trouver des hommes de bonne volonté qui consentirent à s'atteler à la tâche de nettoyer cette écurie d'Augias.

div.head: AFFAIRES IMMOBILIÈRES.
div.p: Plusieurs confrères ont parlé, tout récemment, de l'affaire des Terrains de Cléopâtre, qui s'est montée à Alexandrie, sous forme de Société civile et dans laquelle la Société d'Entreprises Immobilières et de Travaux de notre ville est intéressée pour environ 10% (c'est-à-dire 30,000 pior).

Nous ne reviendrons pas aujourd'hui sur la valeur de l'affaire ; obso on sait que c'est une des plus brillantes qui aient été faites cez temps derniers, mais le bruit ayant couru que la Société civile avait revendu son domaine à un autre groupe, nous croyons pouvoir dire que des propositions ont bien été faites dans ce Sens - et même avec une offre de bénéfice considérable - mais qu'elles n'ont pas été acceptées.

On nous assure, par contre, qne la Société d'Entreprises Immobilières et de Travaux prépare elle même, en ce moment', un projet en vae de transformer en "Société anonyme" la Société Civile des Terrains de Cléopâtre. Cette Société anonyme pourrait indifféremment être égyptienne ou de toute autre nationalité (et. avoit, si ses promoteurs le jugent opportun, des parts de foodster, poi qu'il y a l'apport de domaine). Bien entendu, les détails devront éventuellement être déterminés par les autres intéressés ou participante.

div.head: MLLE BRANDES IN CAIRO.
div.p: "L'AMOUREUSE."
(FROM OUR THEATRICAL CORRESPONDENT.)
que,
chear fatigue,
the fever be

"L'Amoureuse" is & most perfect play ; faultlessly devised, shaped, and finished, fall of wit and delicate audacity, free from proposing mr arduous reflections, and, above all, exquisitely roethlis in its character drawing: it might be Targénieff dramatized. The scheme occurs to one as might that of some most perfect concentrated sonatins : -the love match, a honeymoon not ended yet after eight years-for the wife---allegretto grazioso, with the least touch of bitter-sweet rubato onder. ying: the husband, resentful: then scherza, reproscb, recrimination, growing exasperation -herein an interlude, & minoet : the former mistra88 appears, eo quiet and ordered, soothing her frettal scientist, who left bis suave, well tempered life with her, to marry, to bind himself to inexperience and at the end a wild, passionate orash, arpeggios culminating in the last discord : bis wife rages in that she, legitimate, may not love him, or give him freely what he would expect from any girl in the street: he, farious, perhaps with shame, 88 well as unreasonable resentment, flinge ber into the arms of their friends. Then the finale. She has yielded, outraged, wild with despair. One remembers the 1st allegro in the "Patbétique," chords flying, pulsating driven on and on in sbeer fatigue, closed at last by the stern, sad bars, gravé: the fever has spent itselt; they cannot part or die; they must live, and bope, and forget.

The husband is a doctor, 43 years old, rather reasonable, and illogical, used to, capable to do with best, petting and adoration, eventful at once when bis wife's impulses or his own break through his and her better judgment He Baorifices, a mission for moment of renascent attraction, and then as she foresees only too clearly, reproaches her for it. She, for all her love and inexperience of Unmanageable men, has hours of olear, keen sight, but her longing and his unreason destroy these, and leave them more bitter than before, until at the last, they come together worn out by one another. They cannot pardon without difficulty and remorse, or make allowance for all they have brought upon themselves, without being realised its fullness. M. Roneselle and Mlle Brandès took these two parts; and for sheer perfection of talent, and faultless incarnation of all the piece meant, they left a memory few players could have inspired : every detail of light and shade was exact and striking. I could write pages upon these two, but, I think, I could say nothing ! that would really bring out more bigby my sense of their acting.

For the rest, M. Goornac was fairly good, bat strack a false comic note once or twice. Mlle Marcilly bad little enough to do. Her dress-or was it the cloak 1--olicited one of the test epigrams in the whole playgarment "qui vous aconse, mais ne vous condamne pas." It must have been the cloak, as I have seen oaks which do dumo. As to dress, though but a mere man, I could not but admire Mlle Brandès' dress in the 3rd sot, rather dark olive, & white, scarcely shown corsage, with some pink touches, and a curious belt. May those who know pardon so balda de soription, and recognize what power They and Their dressmakers posse overmale destinies 1-But then she is always a most attractive creature,80 eepple, and virile in every intonation and movement.

IBA some of the cortaid-raiser-dell enough, in all consulence. Mlle Marcilly looked very attractive, and had a most excellent if slightly colourless voice (that might be said of ber action.. though in that she certainly Shows more independence than most of the casta). I could hear every word she said, right at the very back of the theatre. M. Alerme appeared as dry and full of subdued wit as ever : but it seemed to be a silly piece.

div.head: STEAMBR MOVEMENTS.
div.p: Tha S.S. Creole Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left London on the 16th inst and is due at Alexandria on or about 2nd January. 1 The 8.8. Trojan Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the 19th inst, and is doe at Alexandria on Monday morning.
The Moss liner Menes arrived this morning from Liverpool, via Gibraltar, A!giers and Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Moss liger Karuak arrived this morning from Glasgow, viâ Gibraltar and Malta, with general cargo.
The Moss liner Tabor sailed from Liverpool yesterday afternoon, and is a judge here about the srd prox. with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Ellerman liner Adalia arrived at Man. Chester yesterday morning..
The Ellerman.liner Ayon exiled last evening for Liverpool direct with a general cargo, including 2,917 baleset ootton.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Princess Salbsh Happen Effendi has been appointed tatores; to her children, and Hassan asha Assem, assistant tator. .
Princess Pakchi Ko Hanem Effendi has been entrusted with the education of her grandson, with Prince Omar Pasha Tour Soon as assisTAnt tutor.

Ghazi Makbtar Pasha recently receive i a Cost from Constantinople, by name Yabbies CHF. Defterdar, who is a public orator of the Holy Shrine of Mecca. The Khatib will proed to the Hedjaz in a few days.

Count von Bernsdorff, the German Minister, as arrived at Alexandria, in order to meet his on, Viscount von Burgsdorff, who became ere in order to spend his holidays in Egypt. The Count is returning to Cairo tomorrow and will entertain the officers of the Charlotte to the ranch at Meda House on Sunday.
Countess von Burgsdorff will not hold ber Monday receptions on the 24th and 31st of this month.

The father in-law of Miralai Hopkinson Bey, Commandant of thé Alexandria City Police, Major General Baron Congleton of Congleton, f Rathleague, Queen's County, Ireland, and f 28, Green-street, Park-lane, W., who died last month, leaving unsettled, property of the

T088 value of £10,715, made heirlooms to follow the devolution of the settled property of The following articles : His swords, me lala, and decorations, all portraits of miniatures of the Parnell or Bligh families, the silver-gilt dessert
service presented by King Willism IV. to his maternal grandmother, Georgiana Charlotte Bligb, seventh daughter of Jobp, seventh Earl of Galloway.

Shedid Bey Habeisb, Ottoman Congal-Goberal in Paris, has arrived in Alexandria, where he was received by his brother Nasmen Bey Habeish, ex-president of the Lebanon Court of Appeal, who came here recently from Byria, and a number of Syrian notables of Alexandria. Shedid Bey belongs to a distingaisbed Maronite family of the Lebanon boarding the title of sheikh. He is staying at the Windsor Hotel and will leave shortly for the Lebanon, where he will spend a few months.
M. Clermont Gapnean, the well-known French Bavant, is on his way to Assouan to make research98.

At H.B.M.'s Consulate, Alexandris, on Wednesday last, the civil marriage was cele. brated of Miss Helen Podesta to Mt. Geo. B. Alderson. The witnesses for the bridegroom were Mr. P.W. Carver and M.G.A Garzovi.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)
Les détecteurs actuels acceptant de payer tous les reports qu'on leur demande et des acheteurs se présentant sur le marché, une reprise aussi générale que inattendue de produit,

Il y a eu des affaires on pea sur tous les titres, mais particulièrement sur ceux dont la spéculation s'est emparé : Cassa di Sconto, Delta Land, Investment, Estates, Comptoir, Building, Union Foncière, Crédit Franco-Égyptien, Agricole et National Bank.

Les fluctuations les plus remarquables sont Ils reprise des Dividendes Tramways de 346 à 350. la hausse des Jouissances Baux da Caire Be 272 & 280, Bébé de 40 & 40 3/4, Cassa di Ponto de 266 # 371 l'ancienne et de 261' 266 la nouvelle, Deferred Delta de 13 1/4 à 13 1/2, Nuo Govich Hôtels de 21 1/2 à 21 3/4, Nile Land de 17 8/4 à 18 acheteurs, Urbain Pe 7 1/2 & 7 11/16, Comptoir de 7 7/16 & 7 8/16 et Union Foncière de 6 3/16 à 6 5/16.
La part de fondateur Comptoir passe de 61 A 70 livros acheteurs.
Les reports pour janvier se font en si grand nombre qu'une prise pour fia décembre semble Définitivement écartée.

div.head: TELEGRAMS.
div.p: DEATH OF EDUCATION BILL.
Memorable SCENE IN THE LORDS.
EVE OF BITTER CONTROVERSY.
LONDON, December 20. Lord Laasdowne's motion insisting on the amendments to the Education Bill has been adopted by 132 votes to 52.

Lord Crewe said that the Government of ir. ed substantial concessions, but that there was still an unbridgeable golf. He laid on the Opposition the responsibility of wrecking the Bill. The Archbishop of Canterbury said that it was better to have no Bill than one marred by saob blemishes.
The Duke of Devonshire voted with the Government.

LONDON, December 20. A memorable scene took place in the House of Lords, in striking contrast to that witnessed in the House of Commons on similar occasions. The Chamber presented a picturesque sight, but the procedure was formal on i dignified and unemotional, differences being mainly narrowed down to the question of prohibiting teachers from giving religious instruction.
The Duke of Devonshire regretted the rapture in the negotiations on this ground.
Lord Crewe declared that their Lordships had deliberately chosen war and it was exceedingly likely that during the coming months many barsh things would be said and done,
Lord Ripon, closing the debate, warded the denominationalism that they would never again get the same terms.

LONDON, December 20. HOUSE OF COMMONS. — With reference to the Lord'message regarding the Education Bill, Sir H. Campbell Bannerman moved that the order be discharged. This emphatic refusal to consider the amendments was received by the Ministerial bedobe: with cheers.
The comments in the newspapers are largely recriminations regarding the possibility for the death of the Bill.

All agree that the country is on the eve of the bitterest controversy. Meanwhile the Government is urged to permit the local authorities to evade payment for denominational teaching by the rigid administration of the existing Act, which deals with inefficient voluntary schools with the utmost severity. It is also urged to j.introduce a short financial bill to assist the local authorities to build new schools.
TRADES DISPUTES BILL.
LONDON, December 20. HOUSE OF LORDS. -It has been decided not to insist on the amendments to the Trades Disputes Bill.
SLEEPING SICKNESS.
DISCOVERY OF THE CURE.

BERLIN, December 20. The Imperial Health Department has pub. lisbød detailed reports of Kooh's sleeping sick. DES core, claiming the success to be due to the use of atoxyl and serom. It attributes to the Boglishmen, Mesers. Grave and Greig, a share in the discovery.
CHURCH AND STATE IN FRANCE.

PARIS, December 20. Up to the present 105 religious establishments, including 34 episcopal palaces, have been evacuated throughout the country. Collisions between mobs and gendarmes took place at Grenoble and Nantes yesterday on the occasion of the ejection of the prelatas. Many arrests were made.
PARIS, December 20. The Saint Sulpice Seminary has been evaluated.
ITALIAN AMBASSADOR TO BERLIN.
ROME, December 20. Signor Pades bas been appointed Ambassador at Berlin.
NEW GOVERNOR OF PALESTINE.

JERUSALEM, December 20. Resim Bey, the newly-appointed Governor of Palestine; who replaces Resbid - Bey, trapeterred to the Vilayet of Monastir, arrived to-day. He was Secretary at Yildiz Kiosk, and is a Ben of Kemal Bey, the famous poet and litterateur.
BIG FIRE AT HARBIN.
MUXOEN, December 20. A fino at Barbin bas destroyed the huge building of the General Staff for the Amur distriot, and many shops and warehouses. (R.)
STEAMER BLOWN UP.
VICKSBURG, December 20. A steamer, whilst loading potton, blow op. A noore of people, mostly negroes, were killed and 19 injurei.
RUISULI'S DISMISSAL REDEMANDED

TANGIER, December 20. The Moorish troops, commanded by Gaeb. bas, Minister of War, and Kid MacLean, will arrive tomorrow and camp outside the city, within the district and rule of El Rsisoli, whose dismissal is again demanded by the Powers owing to the merciless public flogging carried out by his orders.
(Router) TANGIER, December 20. The Cherifi in troops under the command of Guebas have arrived near here to maintain order.
LOAN FOR WÉST AFRICA.
PARIS, December 20. The Chamber has authorised West Africa to borrow 100 millions (francs). (Havas)

div.head: THREE PHARAOHS IN CAIRO.
div.p: BY REV. E. J. HARDY, M.A. Senior Chaplain, Army of Occupation, Bgypt, author of "How to be Happy Though Mar.
ried."

Many are the interested placas to be seen in Cairo, but none is more worth a visit to the Museum at Kasr-el Nil. The Egyptologist may food in the British Museum, the Louvre, and elsewhere, things & instructive as spy that are in the collection in question, but to students of the Bible the Cairo mummies of the Pharaohs that are mentioned in that book are of unique value, speaking as they do acr088 nearly forty centuries. The Biblical Pharaohs, 80 to speak, in the Cairo Museum are three in number. Seti I, Ramses II., and Meneptab III. These were all called Pharaohs, for Phs. raob was not a name but a title, and one that was given to every king of Egypt. It meant "the great house" (or gate), and BO W8S identical with the Sublime Porte of more recent times.

Seti I. was a contemporary of Jacob, and it seems scarcely possible to believe as we look on that brown-black but still handsome face that its owner was born 3,272 years ago. When he ascended the throne bis kingdom was threatened on all side, but he not only gained for it security but he conquered Syria, Mesopotamia, Nubia, and Pant or Somaliland Pharaoh Seti I. was reigning when Joseph was sold into Egypt, and it was with that small but clever-looking head that he dreamed of the seven fat cattle and the seven thia ones, of the seven good ears of corn and the seven blasted ones. From one of those mommied fingers he took his biguet ring and put it on & finger of Joseph, and he arragged hat as & still further mark of his approbation the interpreter of his dreams should marry the daughter of a high ecclesiastic, the dean, 80 to speak, of the great temple of the Sun at On, afterwards called Heliopolis. Seti I. told Joseph to bring to Egypt his father and kinsmen. With that leather like mouth which we look at to day the king aske i Jacob when presented to him, "How many are the days of the years of thy life?' And Jacob said into Pharaoh, "The days of the years of my pilgrimage are an hundred and thirty yaara."

No father was ever pronder of a son than was Seti I. when Ram 98e3 II. was born 3239 years ago. Seti was not himself of royal descent, but being married to a princess who was their son Rameses II. was of the royal line. When only an infant he was appointed officer commanding the bodyguard and officer commanding the chariots.

When he grew up and became a real warrior he was bravery itself. On one occasion in a campaign eg sinst the Hittites through the fault of the intelligence department was separated from his army. He dashed his chariot with each impetuosity against the foe that they took him for a god and pushed and trampled each other into the river Orontes. When his officers came up they were astonished at the beeps of those who were slain by his own band. You forsook me," he said bitterly, "and I had no friends but my horses; henceforth they shall come into my palapa and eat their cora in my presence."

Rameses II. always took a lion with him on his campaigns. He captured many great cities, including Jerosalem. He left his kingdom the largest and most powerful of that day. He was called the stench Dames & Lord of Light," "Star of the Morning," "Jackal of the South." His wives (those were the good old times.) performed religious devotions before him. Rameses seems really to have thought that be was a god, for he played his statue in the holy of holies of the temple of Abu Simbel amongst the gods. | Rameses II. might be called the Napoleon I. and the Michael Angelo of ancient Egypt. The first part of his reign was spent in capturing slaves, and with these, during the second part, be built temples and erected monuments chiefly in his own bonoor, Ove gets tired of his name in Egypt as we do of that of Micbael Angelo in Italy. Though a great 800andrel he was a splendid artist.
Rameses II. was a man of great stature, physical strength, and personal beauty. He lived over eighty years and reigned six'y-reven. His wives were three in number and his children 170.

Rameses II. was the king who knows not Joseph." It was his daughter who foundMoses in the bulrushes when his mother had placed him there in partial obedience to the king's decree that all male Israelitish children should be put into the Nile.

Perhaps no human being ever had so much oourt paid to him as bad Rameses II. He had conquered all the neighbouring countries, and ordinary kings thought it an honour to ki 38 the dust when he raised his feet. 'be distinction of being allowed to kies the fet them. selves was only granted to very exalted sovereign indeed. And now he is a gazing-stock to giggling, thoughtless tourists

The words "God tempers the wind to the shorn lamb" are generally supposed to be in the Bible. They are not, however, but in a book by Lawrence Sterne. In the same way people used to think that the Bible related that the Pharaoh who oppressed the people of Israel was drowned in the Red Sze. The Bible only says that Pharaoh's army was lost. While Eastern monstrebi that he was, be reminded on terra firma to see what would happen.

Certainly we who live in Cairo know that his body was not los“, tor every time we go into the Masem we see it there as large as life, if we may bo speak of one who has been a mummy for thirty-two centaries. The mummy of Merneptah II., son of Ramesses II., who was the Pharaoh of the Buodas, has never been aprolled, but it has been identified by mark

inge on the swathing bands. Underneath these wrappings are the very lips that said in the language of his time and country-"Wherefore do ye, Moses and Aaron, loose the people from their works! Get you onto your bardens" (Revised Version)

In Exodus i. we read that the Israelites "built for Pharaoh store cities Pithom and Raamses." The few remains of these cities have bəen carefully examined, and it is said that parts of them are composed of bricks made with straw, others of bricks held together by bits of reed when the supply of straw or stubble bad given ont, and yet others parts of bricks in which there is neither straw nor reeds. This is thought to be a confirmation of the Bible story.
It has been forged as a disparagement of the Biblical record that there is no mention on the monuments of Joseph or of M08es.

The negative argument from silence, bow. ever, is not oonolosive. The Israelites were a small and despised people, and the Egyptia Ds did not record, we may be sure, upon their monuments anything that balittled themselves.

Then a large amount of writing upon papyrus or even apon stone has been lost, or rather, has never been found. Any day a "find" may be made of tablet or papyrus corroborating the Bible narrative in relation to Egypt. Bat why shouldn't the Bible be as oredible as any record out on the wall of a tomb or elsewhere? Why might we not argue that the statements on the monuments are not true because they are not allowed to in the Bible 1 ("Banday at Home.")

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT

Liverpool, December 13. I For Egyptian ootton on the spot thera bas been a moderate demand, quotations of both Brown and Upper being raised to 1. per lb. Fine Brown, however, is 1 d. per lb. dearer There has been a fairly active business in Pateros, and the following are the latest values :
Dec. 10.8 Mar. 10.7 Jane 10.10 Jan. 10.6 April 10.8 July 10.10

Feb. 10.6 May 10.10 Aug. 10.8 American Futures. The market this week has displayed considerable weakness, and prices at one time showed a decline of about 30 points. Tu day a better feeling has prevailed, and there has been a recovery of about 9 points from the lowest rates touched. The chief interest has centred round the Census Ginners' report, which came about as anticipated, Damely 10,023,000 bales, and the Baread report of the estimated yield, which is given at 12,546,000 bales, was apparently the signal for & very determined "Bear" raid, for prices in the American market fell about 60 points. Our market stood op fairly well, and took a good deal of contracts on Straddle from America; consumers also purchased freely on the decline. As an estimate of the yield, we cannot consider the figures of the Bread warrant the decline, for we have been assured from all sides for many weeks past that the crop would be 13, 13), or even 14 millions. We are inclined to think that the Bureau report has this reason been compiled with unusual care, and with the greatest desire not to orr on the small side; we therefore believe that this estimate is Substantially correct. The enormous sales of forward cif. cotton before the season was well opened, and the great money stringepoy which has prevailed in the States must in our opinion have operated to move the orop with congenital rapidity; the heavy movements seem to reflect these conditions.

PIVB-A-BIDE COMPETITION The committee of the Egyptian State Railway Institute Football Club announce that a five-a-side football competition for gold and silver medals presented by Mr. P. H. Trevi. thick will take place on the Institute ground I at Gbeziret Badran, commanding at 2 p.m. on 23rd and 24th January, 1907. Bonafide football clubs only. are admitted. Military entries must be company teams only, whose entrance application must be accompanied by a certificate signed by the company's officer stating that each player has been in the company for at least three months. All appli. cations must be sent to the honorary secretary of the B.R.I.D.E. C, Gh ziret Badrane Cairo, not later than January 10, 1997, accompanied by an entrance fee of P.T. 25 por team. A l'occasion de l'approbation des prés verbaux, M. Salvago dit que dans le oompterenda communiqué à la page de in der Nière séance, il est relaté que la décision prise par la Commission & Bajet des nouvelles taxes, l'a été sur sa proposition. IL rappelle que cette décision est basée sur une proposition de Comité des Finances et s'il avait simplement demandé la mise aux voix de la proposition de Comité.

M. de Monaco dit que ce même compter epda De mentionne pas la protestation de certains membres contre la cotare des débats, alors q 20 des points essentiels restaient encoro à élucider et qae divara arguments à opposer au principe de la nouvelle imposition n'avaient pas encore été développés ; il demande que la Commission mette en mesure les membres qui ont des objections au projet, de les faire valoir afin de donner à la discussion toute l'ampleur qu'elle mérite.

Padoa bey fait remarquer que la Commission D'ayant pris au sujet des nouvelles taxes qu'une décision de principe subordonnés à l'étude de détails que les Comités compétents doivent entreprendre, le champ reste ouvert pour tout développement ultérieur,
Mention est faite de l'envoi aux membres des procès-verbaux de la Commission des 6, 13 et 20 novembre 1906.
Cette communication de donne lien à agonDO observation.
Communication est donnée des lettres suivantes do S.B. le Ministre de l'Intérieur : 1. Jane lettre da 9 Décembre 1906 approuvant

les crédits ouverts par la Commission dans sa abadie da 28 Novembre ; 2. one lettre do 6 Décembre désapprouvant le projet d'arrêté relatif aux joeun d'orgue de barbarie et d'orchestrations; 8. une dép bobo da 29 Novembre approuvant la décision relative à la nomination da nouvel Ingénieur en chef.

La Commission renvoie à de nouvelle étape de la Délégation et des Comités des Finances et des Travaux Publics réunis, la demande présentée par M.G. Ralli pour la concession d'un terrain sur les quais en vae de l'érection
d'on Casino. 1 La question des scoorde intervenir avec

M. O. Joseph préalablement à la concession d'ane jetée au Port-Est est renvoyée au Comité du Contentieux qui voudra bien présenter son rapport à la prochaine séance. | Sar la demande da la Délégation, la Commission autorise une dépense supplémentaire de 45 LB, á régulariser ultérieurement, pour frais nécessités par le Service de Désinfection.
La Commission, sur la demande de la Délégation adopte, staff' pour trois d'entre elles, La Vorbes à une proobsins sanoo, les décisions

relatives aux excédents et emprise, dont question aux procès-verbaux des 13 Novembre. ler Déc. et 4 Décembre 1906. La superficie de terrain que la Délégation était autorisée à vendre, ayant été vendue presque en totalité, l'Administrateur demande
De nouvelle autorisation pour la mise en vente de 50 à 100,000 pièce dos terrains des
quais. ! Mr. Fenderl dit qu'il faut activer bons ventos,

our les terrains à bâtir devenant de plus en plas rires en ville, les habitants sont obligés de se répandre dans la baiocco, facto de LOCAUX suffisants; il demande que la Délégation soit autorisée à mettre immédiatement en vente, un minimum de 100,005 pios.

Mr Bicoffior propose de laisser pleins pouvoirs à la Délégation pour décider des quantités et des époques qu'elle jagers le plus favorables pour les ventes.-La Proposition de Mr. Bouffier est adoptée.

Bar an exposé du Président et, étant donné que les frais de construction se sont sensiblement élevés depuis l'époque où des prélimi. naires d'entente ont été établis avec le Con. salat de France, en vue de l'échange de son terrain de la Place Méhémet Aly contro un terrain plus petit situé sur les quais, plos une somme de 14,000L B pour les frais de construction d'un nouvel Hôtel Consolera ; étant donné, d'autre part, le grand intérêt: que présente pour l'hygiène, l'aération e: l'esthétique de la ville, l'exécution de projet de création d'une place aor l'emplacement des terrains du Coustalat, la Commission vote une contribution supplémentaire de LB 14,00) portant . LE 25,000 les dépenses assumées par la Ville pour la construction de l'Hôtel Consulaire de Prado, somme qui sera versée au Consulat dans les conditions établies par la première entente, et à charge par le Consulat de remettre, aussitôt l'accord définitif canola, le terrain faisant l'objet de l'échange pour per. mettre à la Municipalité d'y commencer les travaux nécessaires et à la condition que la oopstraction de l'Hôtel Consulaire soit terminés dans un délai maximum de trois ans, à partir de la conclusion dudit sourd.
La réanos est levée à 7 b. 80 p.m.

div.head: His Britannic Majesty's Consulate at Alexandria.

All persons neglecting so to register themselves are liable to legal penalties.
The consulate will be open daily from 10 A.m. till noon for the delivery of registration certificates.

div.head: The Khedivial Mail Steamship and Craving Dook Company, Ltd.
div.p: NOTICE 18 HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the abovedamed Company will be held at Winchester House, Old Broad Street, London, E.C., on Monday, the 31st day of December, 1906, at | 12.35 o'clock in the afternoon, for the purpose
of considering, and it deemed advisable, passing I the following Resolution with or without modification.

RESOLUTION. "That the hospital (f the Company be increased to £400,000 by the creation of 100,000 new Ordinary Shares, and that in lieu of each new shares being offered in the manner provided by Article 13 of the Company's Articles of Association, the Directors be and are hereby authorised and empowered to issue the said new shares upon such terms as to price, and on such conditions as to underwriting, and other wise, and at each times, and generally in each madder as they may deem expedient, and whether in the form of bearer shares, or registered sharer, or partly in one form and partly in the other, provided always that the Directors shall give a preferential allotment of euch new shares to the holders of Ordinary and Preference Shares of the Company in proportion to their respective holdings."
Should the Resolution be passed by the required majority it will be submitted for confirmation ss & Special Resolution to & second Extraordinary General Meeting, which will be subsequently convened.

In the event of a bearer of a Share Warrant desiring to vote at the above-mentioned Meeting, he must on or before the 20th day of December, 1906, deposit such Share Warrant! with the Imperial Ottoman Bank, Alexandria, or on or before the 24th day of December, 1906, with Messrs. Glyn, Mills, Corrie and Co., 67 Lombard Street, London, B.C.
By order of the Board, L. HALLIDAY
Secretary Dated this 30th day of November, 1906. No. 72 Bishopsgate Street Within, London, B.C.

div.head: BANQUE D'ATHÈNES
div.p: Messieurs les Actionnaires sont convoqués en Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire le Samedi 30/12 Janvier 1907, à 11 heures du matin, au siège Central à Athènes.
• ORDRE DU JOUR Election du Directeur Général en remplacement de leu Jean G. Pesmazoglou.
Aux termes de l'article 35 des statuts, ont seule droit de prendre part à l'Assemblée, les Actionnaires possédant au moins 50 (cinquante) Actions.

Les Actions devront être déposées, d'après l'article susmentionné, à Athènes au Siège Central, ou dans toute autre Banque autorisée ; pour la Grèce, la Crète ainsi que Alexandrie, le Caire, Londres, Constantinople, Smyrne et Salonique, dans les Succursales de la Banque, et à Paris, à la Banque de l'Union Parisienne.

Les récépissés de dépôt des titres ainsi que les pouvoirs devront être adressés au siège Central (Service des titre) jusqu'au 257 Janvier 1907, un soir, où il sera délivré aux Actionnaires de carte d'admission pour l'Assemblée. Athènes le 29/11 Décembre 1906. Le Président du Conseil d'Administration
M. JORDAN. ULO 29101-124.-2

div.head: CRÉDIT FONCIER EGYPTIEN.
div.p: Messieurs les Actionnaires sont convoqués à l'Assemblée Générale Ordinaire qui aura lieu le Jeudi 31 Janvier 1907 , 3 berres de l'après-midi, au siège social, au Caire.
ORDRE DU JOUR. 1.-Léotard da Rapport du Conseil d'Admi. nistration sur les Affaires sociale; ; y compris l'affaire ozonol ne avec la Société Égyptienne de la Daïra Sanieh, définitivement réglée.
2.-Leotare de Rapport des Caesars;
3.-Approbation des comptes et fixation da dividende pour l'exercice 1906;
4.-Nomination d'Administrateurs ;
5.-Nomination de deux Censeurs pour l'exercice 1907.

Tout porteur de 50 Actions & le droit d'assister à l'Assemblée Générale et conformément à l'article 28 des Statuts, les Actions devront être déposées : En Egypte, an plus tard le 80 Janvier 1907; En Europe, au plus tard le 20 Janvier 1907;
Les dépôts seront reçues : Au Caire, au siège Social; A Alexandrie, su Crédit Lyonnais ; En Europe, & la Banque de Paris et des Pays

div.p: NOTES BT CRITIQUES

Le Caire, Jeudi 20 Décembre 19 6. Le taux de l'8800mpte libre à Londres se maintient à 6 o/o. Hier, sur Stock Exchange, lo Consolidé anglais est resté avarié à 86 1/4, de même que l'Unifiés à 103. La National Bank et les autres valeurs égyptiennes sont demeurées inchangées à leurs cours précédents.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Égyptien a avancé de 5 franga & 789. LA Banque d'Athènes s'est maintenue à 138. L'Emprunt russe 1906 & passé de 86,50 & 85,60.

loi, le marché des valeurs & été, ce matin, relativement animé, avec des cours plas 800 topus qa'bier. Las transactions restent natural. lement restreintes, comme il convient à cette époque de l'année, avec les fêtes de Noël en perspective.

Un autre motif d'abstention est ls liberté persistante ds l'argent, charte appelée, toutefois, à s'atténuer d'ici aq 31 Déc ambre ou bien aussitôt après cette grande échéance qui marque ordinairement le retour de l'aiss noé. Ba attendant, la sainte d'ana fin de mois de généralement laborieuse s'amoindrit, la position de place de trouvant allégée et assainie par les nombreuses liquidations forcées de nos jours derniers. Une bonne rep-188 De sa parait dono tarder à se produire, peut-être même plus vite qu'on ne le croit généralement.

Dans lo compartiment des Banques, la National a progressé à 28 1/8. L'Agricole s'est maintenu à 9 9/16. La Cassa di Sconto est remontée à 2 is et le Comptoir Financier à' 7 7/16. La Banque d'Athènes & été également misog tonge à 187–138.
Le Créan Foncier est resté i 782. L. Dira s &vanoé à 17 7/16.

L'action Bat Reprises Immobilières et Travaux qui avait clôturé hier à 14 1/4, a débuté 80 jourd'hui de même pris pour avancer à 15 et revenir à 14 1/1. Cette réaction est explicable: sachent avoir affaire quelques vendeurs azieux de réaliser le bénéfice acquis depuis la veille, les acheteure s'emploient, tout naturellement, à s'assurer le titre aq plus bas prix possible. Ces petites opérations ne modifient en rien la position. L'opinion prédo. minants on Board est toujours que le règlement des engagements fia odorant ménage du grosses surprises.
La part de foo date a été traitée entre P.E 102 et 100.
Les Aliments se sont maintenus à 3 7/8; leor part de fondateur a bsassé do 142 & 159.
Ba bonne tendance, les Jouissance Brox da Caire ont gagoo 6 fand 280. Les Automobiles sont remontées à 6 7/8-6.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nangovich se sont alourdis 22 1/4-3/8. L: Egyptian ont avado à 9 11/16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, Is Delta Land, en fort bonne disposition, a bénéficié de 3/16 à 4 9/16-5/8. Los Estates se sont raffermis à 2 3/8-7/16, les Markets à 30 sh. 3 et les New Egyptian à 32 sb. Les Khedivial Mdil ont progressé à 39 sh. 6.
· Le conseil d'administration de l'Egyptian Land and General Trust Ltd. (Hooker) a décidé de fixer au 15 Janvier prochain l'appel da troisième quart do 5 shelliage par action.
Le quatrième quart de 5 sbsl linge, libérant complètement le titre, sera appelé le 15 Mars 1907.

Ainsi qu'on a da le constater, nous avons rétabli depuis hier ci-contre, dans le tableau a des cours de cette Circulaire, le prix des titres de l'Epargne Immobilière Ltd., que nous avions remplacé par une barre à la suite de la fameuse mesure d'interdiction da 27 Novembre dernier.

Ls valeur étant traités quand même en Bourse, nous donnerons désormais journellement les courg pratiq nós. Aujourd'hui l'action Epargne Immobilière Ltd. a été échangée aux environs de 3 et la part de fondateur entre P.R. 60 et 65.
Si nos informations sont exactes, on va prochainement procéder à l'émission publique des Caffari Co-operative Markets Ltd.

Ainsi que notas l'avons déjà annoncé dans notre Oir Lalaing du ler Décembre, M. Paol Oziol, président de la Corporation das Agents de change da Caire, est administrateur et M. Joseph Jabes, de la maison Ozol, Fabès et Cie., censeur de ostte nouvelle Société.
Bo même temps que l'assemblée-annuelle ordinaire, une assemblée générale extraordi. paire des actionnaires de la Salt and Soda Ltd. est convoquée pour le 27 Décembre courant au Caire.

Blle bera invitée à ratifier les arrangements intervenus relativement à la suppression des 1,000 parte de fondateur de la Société et au remplacement de ces parts par 50,000 actions ordinaires additionnelles.
Les recettes des Egyptian Markets pour la semaine au 6 Décembre courant ont été de L.E. 750 contre 744 en 1905, soit en augmentation de L.A. 6.
Las recettes totales depuis le ler Janvier 1906 s'élèvent à L.B. 31,187 contre 28,824 en 1905, soit en plus-value de LB, 7,363.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers “Osiris" and “Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy’s most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, “Entombment," by Ciseri, and ‘Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D’OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: FRESKEL.
div.p: WHAT IT IS
FRESKEL is a dry powdered preparation for Wall and Ceiling Decoration, made ready for use with the addition of water.
It is easily prepared and applied.
WHAT IT DOES
FRESKEL, covers well, and works easy Does not crack, peel, or show brush marks. Does not rub off.
ECONOMICAL - EFFECTIVE.
Shade Cards and Circulars on application to the manufacturers:
THOS. HINSHELWOOD & CO., LIMITED. ALEXANDRIA.
